Left at 10 PM & came back to the ship
Entry.146:
Leave first thing in the morning so we went ashore early. Took a couple of snaps at the Apollo Bunder & then did a little shopping. Had dinner & then went to Victoria Gardens which are in the outskirts of the city. the Museum & Zoo are in the garden grounds. The grounds are very well layed out & a fine collection
s



of animals are to be seen. The Indians visit here in large numbers & seem to delight in looking at the various attractions. Came back & had 
arol
a final look at the city then walked along the main road to the Taj-Mahal Hotel for tea. Every European in Bombay seemed to be there & after an hours wait we had our tea. It was very intresting watching the different manners of the people. Fun started on the first floor in the Lounge when a couple of the boys took possession of the piano & gave songs etc.

Two English generals were there & many other officers of all ranks with their wives etc. The Karoola chaps entertained so well that the General shouted champagne to all the boys. One could see a private (merry ?) between two officers (merry ?) laying the law down that a private was as good as an officer & they agreed too. Leave expired at 1 AM majority rolled ? home at 5AM Ada Reeves was there & gave a couple of songs.
Entry.147:
At 6 AM we weighed anchor & went into the Dock area. This took time

as we had to go through a lock. Embarked about 350 patients on & then left at high tide about 4 PM, heading for Aden. The patients were given their tea & they seem a nice lot. All are sick cases & there are forty Mental cases.
Entry.148:
Things are not quite settled yet. The mental cases have taken a good few orderlies so we are short handed. The patients are very quiet to the Australians. The "Tommy" Officers are some swank. Busy getting the patients equipment

down to the store this afternoon.
Entry.149:
Cleaned ward up with the assistance of two patients. They are naval men & are very handy. The rest of the patients are good fellows. They all like the Australian tucker very much.

the weather is very humid & hot The sea is calm
Entry.150: Did usual work in the ward, which is much easier, having obtained more assistance. The patients received an issue of Red Cross goods today. The run was305 miles.
Entry.151: Did usual work in the ward. Sea very calm but weather is hot. Had an impromptu concert at night by the patients. Did 327 miles.
Entry.152: Still very hot. Church service for patients at 10.30 AM Had a read & swim in afernoon. Most of the patients are getting off at Suez.
Entry.153:
Arrived at Aden about 1.30 AM moored at 2 AM Aden is a small well fortified place. The population consists mostly of garrison men. The town is situated

at the bottom of a steep hill. The houses are flat roof & small, being painted with different colours. Took on seven patients & left at 11 AM for Suez. Did usual routine in the wards.
Entry.154: Kept insight of land all today. Very warm & sea is calm. At night we passed Perim Island the entrance to the Red Sea. Did the usual work in the ward & developed films at night, in a linen press in E2. Very hot work. Maurice Hale did a couple also.
Entry.155: Very hot in wards. Sea very calm & out of sight of land. Did usual work in ward & in afternoon had a swim. Took a snap of patients in E2 Ward. Did 322 miles run. Patients leaving at Suez number 286 & kits have to be brought up.
Entry.156: Did usual Work in the ward. Have been insight of land all day. Patients are ready to Disembark. It is very cold at night. Had a concert on the Deck.
Entry.157:
Arrived at Suez about 8PM & anchored outside

the breakwater. Naval & Military authorities came aboard, also an armed guard for the gang-way, but left shortly after. Had all patients ready for disembarkation. Very cold at night.
Entry.158:
Not disembarking patients at Suez taking them on to Port Said. Suez seemed much the same as when here last time. We remained out in the stream all the time. Weighed anchor at 12.30 PM & went into the canal. A Dutch boat went ahead of us. all the way up. A British monitor is still stationed

here, also a French cruiser. Made up the canal at the limited rate. The removal of a number of camps was noticeable, also several fortifications Arrived at Ismalia at 8PM & anchored till midnight there being other ships coming up the Canal from Port Said from Ismalia up to Said there are no camps. The Armenian Camp is still at the entrance to the canal. Anchored in practically the same place as last trip. Boats came along side on
Entry.159:
They were selling different Oriental goods. Had patients ready to disembark but again it has been

cancelled, patients going to Alexandria by the ship. Heedless to say all are pleased. (that is the patients). We have been fooled somewhat in getting hospital equipment away. Had to get the hospital suits back & every patient has to wear them in case we are stopped or seen by a submarine. The staff have to wear a large Geneva Cross on the left arm of their tunic. The ship took on coal & water today. All llights had to be out by 6 PM 
owing to
 as enemy aeroplanes are expected any time, & they would naturally go for shipping. The ship

alongside of us had a bomb dropped on her bow a day before we arrived last time. Officers had leave. The authorities ar very strict here, & no one having a foreign name is allowed ashore. It is wretched on deck with the light out. An impromptu concert was held.
Entry.160:
The Tug came alongside at 4PM & we moved out of the harbour passing down the line very slowly. A number of warships' scouts were in. We made full steam to Alexandria & at 4 AM had to slow as the port is closed from sunset

to sunrise
Entry.161:
As we entered the breakwater we passed alongside a sunken vessel which I believe was mined outside & they had tried to beach it. The stern was out of water showing bent & twisted plates where the explosion had occurred. Made straight for a wharf, passing several British cruiser. All patients were prepared for disembarkation which commenced at 2PM. At 4PM we left for Malta. Alongside of us was H.S." Exquibo" which had some of the 14th A.G.H. on for England. It

was very calm at sea, & we started to race the other Hospital Ship. the weather is cold.
Entry.162:
Usual routine in the wards. The ward seemed empty with only two patients. However they gave a hand & we cleaned the ward up. Have caught up to the other hospital ship. Had Boat Stations & all patients had to be brought up on deck. We finished our wards E1.2.3. in four minutes of course we had all ports closed in anticipation. The sea is very calm.

Develped with Maurice Hale twelve spools of exposures.
Entry.163: Did usual work in the ward. Sea came up at night, so most of the patients are sick. Wind is strong & cold.
Entry.164:
Did usual work & cleaned up well as the Governor of Malta was expected aboard. Arrived in sight of land at 8AM but had to keep out till 2PM when we went into a small bay until the Grand Harbour was clear. Small boats came alongside & we bought Post Cards from them. Stayed there all night. the bay is very

open & mine-sweepers were out sweeping.
Entry.165:
Weighed anchor at 8AM & made a wide course to Valletta the capital of Malta. Passed through a narrow breakwater into the harbour. The town is built on the old walls of the city, & is about a hundred feet above the sea. Numerous forts are to be seen. Made for the docks & went alongside., Near by was the "Ceramic". A number of destroyers were on dock & mine layers. Patients came aboard at 2PM & we left at 4PM with a full

complement. The Maltese are white, & are from Italy. They seemed to be far in advance of the Gypos' or Indians. Lace which has a great name is largely made here. The city seemed very large from the sea & owing to the height on which it is built, stands out prominently. It is the British Naval Base for the Mediteranean Fleet. The population is about.
Entry.166:
Patients are all from Solonika. They give it a bad name, in regards to weather & general conditions they have had trouble

with scarcity of food. Most have dysentery and Rheumatism. They seemed alright, & in much better condition than those who came onat Bombay,

Sighted land about dinner time, the coast of Africa. Sea very calm. Had usual church service.
Entry.167: Did usual work in ward. . sea a little rough & weather very cold. Lost sight of land in afternoon. Patients are a little sea sick. Did 326 miles run.
Entry.168:
Snow on ranges on the African coast. Wind very sharp, & a dull morning

The sea is very calm. Have land on either side of us. Patients are still sick. Lovely afternoon.
Entry.169: Arrived at Gibraltar early last night. The rock was one blaze of lights. Anchored opposite the breakwater, where many warships were lying. At 9 AM we took on a few patients leaving for Southampton at 10AM. Passed a French Submarine on our way out. Kept insight of land all the day. the coast of Spain seems to be well layed out into small farms. A volcano could be seen smouldering inland.
Entry.170:
25thJanuary 1917

Had a follwoing sea all day. Vey cold in the wards. Did usual ward work.
Entry.171: In the Bay of Biscay wind & sea very strong. Did 302 miles. Patients are all sick & down to it. very cold.
Entry.172:
Ran into Gale & Blizzard early. progress was very slow. Snowing all day so had a snow ball fight on the deck, there being no patients on deck. The decks were awash & we went out of our course, as the sea was

too rough. The masts Bridge & decks were covered with snow. The run being 132 miles for 24 hours.
Entry.173: Still snowing & very rough sea. Did 5 miles an hour. Arrived at Isle of Wight a day late anchoring a few miles out as the boom was down. Numerous ships are waiting outside. The cold is terrific, it being impossile to get warm.
Entry.174:
Anchored off Netley Hospital & remained there till 4PM when we moved up to the docks & disembarked the

patients. The dock waters were covered over with ice an inch thick. After all patients had left the ship was cleaned & all articles returned to the stores. Finished at 10PM & then had a parade for leave. I had the first five days commencing on Tuesday morning. Prepared my kit to take away.
Entry.175:
Up at 5AM & dressed having a little to eat. Arrived at the station train leaving at 6.45AM for London. the ship went out into the stream at 6.30AM Arrived in London & had a general walk around

getting information about trip to Scotland. Had dinner and in the afternoon went out to see the Crystal Palace, a huge pleasure building made of glass. It is now occupied by the Admiralty. Wrote a few letters at Y.M.C.A then went to Kings Cross Station getting train for Edinburgh which left at 10.30 PM. Both of us had good sleep, train arriving in Edinburgh on
Entry.176:
Arrived at Edinburgh at 8AM going to Y.M.C.A. for breakfast. After this we went to hire a room, recommended by the Y.M.C.A. It proved to be very clean & comfortable.

After breakfast we started to see Edinburgh. The most important being Edinburgh Castle, St Giles Cathedral John Knox's house and Holyrood Palace this being the King's residence when in Edinburgh. The Castle is used for a a hospital and commands an excellent view of the city. John Knox's House proved interesting also the localty as it was once the main street of the Old city. Next to the palace is the ruins of an old Abbey. Queen Mary in her time had occupied this place. Made back to the city, having dinner. Food is cheaper here than in London.

Bought a few curios of the city & souvenirs. Snow fell a little all day. Ice skating proved the attraction of the day. Retired very early being very tired & foot sore, having had heavy boots on. The Railway Station is a very large magnificent building although not compact. Scott's monument is also very good. Princes Street the main street is wide a very pretty. The trams are electric. The people seem business like & are obliging.
Entry.177:
Maurice and self up at 7am having early breakfast, then went Kodaks for prints



Caught 9.30 AM train for Dundee. Snow covered the fields & hills. The country seemed deserted. The fields are similar to those in England although they are divided by fences, wood & stone. Crossed over the Forth & Tay bridges both being huge structures. The Tay bridge is 2Â½ miles in length. Arrived in Dundee at noon, going through the streets to the town. Caught tram to Craigie & after a few minutes walk found Mr Paton's house. Mrs Paton was surprised to see us but gave us a cordial welcome. Had dinner & Mr Paton

took us to his office. Had a look at
Durban
Dundee. It is a manufacturing centre the chief industry being Jut & Canvas manufacturing. The streets are narrow & at this time was very muddy. The electric trams are very cheap & have a good service. All city conveniences are controlled by the Council. Mr Paton is an alderman.
Entry.178:
Had an excellent sleep getting up at 10 AM. Had breakfast and then walked through the park (which was covered with snow) to the town. Bought Post Cards of Dundee. Introduced to

Rev Ferguson of Dundee a very nice gentleman. Once in Australia, & knows Rev John Ferguson & other eminent men of Sydney. Went to Nine Wells by tram, & very nice ride along the bank of the Tay. Walked back along the Promenade a very fine walk. Went under the Tay Bridge & made our way to the town.Came home with Mr Paton & had tea. There are five children, the two eldest boys are on active service. The girl is at College & the other two at school. Left at 7pm after saying goodbye & thanking them for treating us so kindly.

Jim Paton came down to the train with us. Arrived at Edinburgh about 9pm & changed to Express which left at 10pm packed, mostly soldiers returning to France. Had a tiring journey down.
Entry.179:
Arrived at King's Cross about 8am. Had a brush up & then went to St Paul's & Cheapside doing a little shopping & then endeavoured to find the "Old Curiosity Shop" which we did after "some" walk. It is an old storey house & now occupied by an old lady who still has a "curiosity shop". Maurice & I separated

I going to Tottenham Court Road Y.M.C.A. to see if any letters were there. Wrote a few letters and had dinner. After dinner I went to Maida Vale to see Colonel & Mrs Atkinson. Had an enjoyable time talking about things in general. They are both very nice. Had tea & left shortly afterwards for Waterloo. Met Maurice & would have gone down to the
station
Southampton Docks but another chap said the ship was in Tilbury Docks - London. After ringing up for a couple of hours, we found that the ship was
all

at Albert Docks, some hour's run from London. Arrived at the ship about 11pm. The ship was in dry dock. Snow fell during night.
Entry.180:
Up at 9am & had breakfast. Ship left the dry dock mooring at wharf outside. All but eight given leave till midnight. I was on guard for an hour. Going on at midnight again. Snow fell very thickly. We are close to recent explosion in London. For miles around traces of it can be observed. About 500 people were killed. Next to us is the "Poona"

in dock having struck a mine in the channel. It has a great gap in Bow.
Entry.181:
Leave from 10am till 12pm. Went over and had a look at the ruins of the recent explosion. It is believed that 1000 were killed and 2000 injured. Large iron structures were torn as if paper & hurled a good distance away. The vicinity is also a huge wreck, terraces of houses being totally destroyed. The explosion was caused by a fire in "T&T" the highest rxplosive used at present. Leaving

here we went to Dr Bernardo's Home for poor children of London. There are no fewer than 7000 children cared for. All are taught a trade so that when of age they can earn a living. Had dinner at the Union Jack Club & then had a stroll down West End doing a little shopping. Went out to Hyde Park & Albert Hall. Snow covered all the park & skating was to be had at Serpentine. Had tea near Trafalgar Square & then went to a theatre. Had to leave early as the station

to where we had to go was some distance. The day was very cold & snow fell all day making the streets very slushy.
Entry.182:
Leave from 10am till midnight. Did not go off till after dinner when Maurice & self went to Guildhall, the Lord Mayor's House & council chambers. Went into the Council room & listened to a few appeals of men not wanting to go to the war. A gentleman showed us a few Historic Books etc & carvings. Leaving here we went to a

service in St Pauls Cathedral. Had tea & went to a theatre at night.
Entry.183: Leave again as before. Had a look at the King opening parliament. The procession was very plain. The King & Queen looked well. Went out to Hampstead Heath & had great fun in the way of Tobogganing. It is ripping going at such a pace over bumps etc. Invariably you fall off. Came to city having tea, then had a walk around the city or rather a small part of it.
Entry.184:
Obtained permission to go off early so as to enable us to get a train to Brighton. Arrived there about noon having dinner. Then went out toQueens Park to the 3rd A.G.H. to see Clarrie Brooks who is a patient there. Had a good talk for an hour or so, then went for a walk down on the Promenade which is very large & fine. The beach is of pebble, not so good as Manly. On the piers are large theatres & Cinema shows. Clarrie was looking very well. The town or rather city is very large & pretty

although the streets are small. Came down to the city & went to the Y.M.C.A. then to the Cinema show. We see the sun a little now.
Entry.185: On guard today. Do an hour on at a time. The ship is very dirty, workmen being everywhere repairing pipes etc. Paint too is on everything, self included. Very cold & frosty. Wrote several letters.
Entry.186:
Leave from 12 noon till Monday midnight. Went out to Col Atkinson's place for week end

Should have gone to a theatre with them in afternoon but was late. Had a game of Bridge at night.
Entry.187: Had excellent sleep. Went to church with Mrs Atkinson, which I enjoyed. Had dinner & then had a read in front of a fire which was really the best place, the weather being so cold. Had tea & then had a game of Bridge.
Entry.188:
Up at 11 o'clock. Colonel gave me some instructions how to play Billiards, & how to hit & aim a ball.

These instructions I tried & they proved to be good. After dinner Mrs Atkinson & I went to a matinee at the Palace "Vanity Fair" the show being very good. After tea had game of Bridge. Left about 10pm getting 10.50 from Fenchurch Station, after spending an enjoyable week-end.
Entry.189: On guard to day. Much warmer. Ship is now painted all over, looking very nice. Wrote a few letters. Half the guard are allowed local leave so I will get off tomorrow.
Entry.190:
Leave from 11am. Had lunch then went to WoolwichArsenal having a look over it. It is a huge work, & about 5000 employed . Large guns & ammunition is made, also various other war implements. In a 15" gun 150 miles of steel wire is used. They have several layers of thick steel to protect the bore, which is made by a huge chisel, which cuts off superfluous steel as though it was wood. Came to town having tea, after which we went to "Romance", a

very good play.
Entry.191: Inspection by Admiralty who was very satisfied with the cleanlineass od ship. Had leave from 4pm till midnight. Went out to Maida Vale to say good-bye to Col & Mrs Atkinson. Had game of Bridge till 10.30pm. Came home & thus ended my leave in Blighty.
Entry.192:
Pulled out from wharf at 6am & stayed in stream till 4pm when it was High tide. Came out of dock & went to South end for the night.

During the day we prepared the wards for patients.

Everyone on board is more or less excited as this is the first Hospital Ship to go out since Blockade. All boats etc are in readiness for any emergency. The sisters are sleeping up in C.3 ward on Promenade Deck. Had Boat Drill.
Entry.193: Came down the Thames as far as Gravesend but owing to the fogs had to anchor for the night. The steering gear also went wrong & they had to wait for some time
Entry.194: A great number of ships of all sizes are anchored around us. Weighed anchor at 9.30 am, but after an hour's steam had to stop owing to fog. Had church conducted by one of the staff. Fog cleared a little. Moved up a little to the boom.
Entry.195:
Fog still dense. Did work in ward till 11 am then had rest of day to self. Played Hockey in afternoon, but lost all ballsover the side as the boats are out. Fog cleared at 8 pm

so went out to sea.
Entry.196: Still afloat on the good ship. Have not seen any submarines although we expect to see one any time. Fog is not so dense. Went with all lights out last night. Destroyers passed us & gave the Captain his position, & warned him of submarines in waters. A lot of wreckage passed during day.
Entry.197:
Took pilot on but could not go in till High tide 4 pm. Ran down a tug which was beached in a sinking condition

Went through the docks & tied up alongside the Hospital ship "Rewa" some of the patients being aboard her as we were not there to time. The cot cases went to a war hospital at Bristol. Did not see anything of the town of Avonmouth.
Entry.198:
Embarked 400 odd patients most being very serious cases. A lot have limbs off. Did not leave the dock till about 6 pm. I am in the Surgical ward D.1. & everyone is a cot case & the majority are helpless. There are ten spine cases

collected all the kit bags & washed the patients. They seem a nice lot of chaps.
Entry.199: Reveille at 6 am. Same routine as previous trip. Washed patients & made their beds. Then had Breakfast. Put Kit bags down No 2 Hold. Cleaned ward. Sea coming up, patients sick. Keeping well out from Bay of Biscay. Off for the afternoon. Go on at 5 pm.
Entry.200:
Lovely day. It seemed strange having sun for so long. Ship did 335 miles

Settling down to the work in ward. Helped to dress wounds on some of the patients. Sea calm.
Entry.201: Church parade at 10.30 am. Have three chaplains on board. Lovely day, patients are doing well as can be expected. They all have ghastly wounds & a number artificial limbs. The spine cases are the worst.
Entry.202:
Sea calm, & an excellent day. Have to attend to Spinal cases with sergeant & another man. Have busy time getting them dressed & cleaned

There are twelve which take all day to do, so we get no time off. The ship did 338 miles.
Entry.203: Usual work in ward splendid weather. Following sea. Patients had an issue of Red Cross goods. They are an excellent lot of chaps. Ship doing good work.
Entry.204:
Settling down to working on spinal cases. Very tedious job, although interesting. Reveille is at 5 am now. Twelve of the staff are in Hospital with sore throats.

etc. Most of us have the same complaint.
Entry.205: Most perfect weather sea is very calm, ship did 356 miles. A good number of patients are getting about the deck with assistance. Passed Cape Verde light House last night.
Entry.206: Patients issued with Red Cross goods. Went into Tropical Uniform to day. All glad to get into them as the Breeches are too hot & tight. Lovely day. Did 344 miles run
Entry.207: Arrived at Freetown capital of Sierra Leone at noon. From the ship the town seems very pretty although it is small. The natives speak English language as well as their own. The Bay is unprotected & the heat is terrific. Malaria is prevalent. About 4000 white people live here. The "Blacks" are of strong physique & clean, to other natives. One of the staff caught a shark. They are numerous in these waters. It is lovely and cool at night.
Entry.208: Very hot day, not a breath of air. Officers went ashore. They said the town was very pretty & clean although there is nothing to see. The houses are very small & strange to say have tin roofs. Very cool at night. Took on coal & water. The coaling is very slow.
Entry.209:
Finished coaling in the morning & left at 3 pm. Brought a few of the Spinal Cases out on deck for fresh air. It is glorious weather. The sea is calm. Band from H.M.S. Royal

Albert came on board & played to the sick.
Entry.210: Very calm at sea & cool. Ship di 344 miles. Patients are all doing well, many being up for a while. The Spinal Cases seem to have improved, & the men treating them.
Entry.211: Very hot down in wards, a good few of the patients are on deck in stretchers. Had concert tonight, very fair. One of our patients played a cornet solo. The sea calm. Did 33 miles to day.
Entry.212: Same work as usual very hot, crossed the line at 11 am. All sleep on deck at night. One of our patients died at 3 pm. The held a P.M. & buried him at 9 pm. The service was very solemn.
Entry.213: A little cooler today, the sea is very calm. Same work as usual in the ward. Run for the day was 323 miles. Impromptu concert held.
Entry.214: Spinal cases are improving gradually. Had them out for alittle fresh air, a move they enjoy. Had concert at night. Sea a little rough run 319 miles.
Entry.215: Divine services as usual. The Chaplains on board are not much good. Ship did 326 miles. Usual work in the ward.
Entry.216:
Another patient died this morning. He gave in about a week ago

& gradually got worse. Did usual work. It is a lovely day,sea calm. Did duty as guard at burial service. He died of T.B. Was buried at 5 PM.
Entry.217: Getting much cooler again & sea coming up. Did usual work in the ward. Mumps have broken out again on the mess decks. Four orderlies have it & there is more to follow. Ship did 326 miles.
Entry.218: Much colder on deck will be glad to get into breeches again. Patients had a Red Cross issue. Passed a ship at noon, the first since leaving Freetown. Concert held on Deck.
Entry.219: Passed round Cape of Good Hope about 3 PM and kept insight of land till dusk. Very windy & cold on deck. Passed a Hospital Ship at night. Did usual work in ward. Patients are much better now that the heat is passed.
Entry.220:
Patients were paid to day, so that they can have an outing at Durban. Keeping a good way out from land this time. Passed a couple of ships.

Sea coming up gradually. Did 318 miles run.
Entry.221:
Had very rough sea making things unpleasant while it lasted. Ship rolled a great deal keeping us awake all night with boxes etc falling over.

Had concert at night. Transferred to to E4 working with Maurice Hale as three weeks on Spinal Cases is enough

for a trip. E4 work is much easier.
Entry.222: Arrived at Durban at 7.30 am going in at 9 am, anchoring at a wharf nearer the town to last time. People came down with books etc for patients. Leave for patients from 2 pm till 8 pm. Motor cars came & gave a good few cot cases a ride around the town. Leave to half the staff from 4 pm till 7 pm. Not much to do in the ward as there were only twelve left.
Entry.223:
Cleaned wards up as usual. Patients off from

2 pm till 8 pm. Half the staff went off from 3 pm till 7.30 pm. Went off into the town & did shopping with Jim Aiken, buying a few souvenirs. Went down to the Esplanade & took a couple of photos, going from there to the Ocean Beach. A great crowd down there, & many of the patients attended by the people of Durban who gave the men a great time, which they appreciated very much. People who owned motor cars lent them unselfishly for conveyance of cot cases to the

pleasure resorts. Had tea then made our way back to the ship, going into the ward & doing ordinary work.
Entry.224: Most of patients very tired. Cleaned up & had dinner. Patients went off at 2 pm till 8 pm. Very hot in sun. Cars came down and took the men out. On duty in afternoon. No leave for staff. Most of us had nothing to do, but could not go off. Had five patients left in E4 ward. Still coaling but will finish tonight.
Entry.225: Finished coaling early this morning. Cleaned up the ward. People came down to say farewell to the patients bringing down little gifts. Pulled out at noon. Lovely warm day, sea very calm. Left Durban in the distance after two hours sailing. All patients speak high of the way they were treated while on leave.
Entry.226:
Headed South East all day. Sea calm. Had concert at night. Did usual work in the

ward. Ship's run 307 miles.
Entry.227: Very cold in morning down below 40Âº Latitude. Now going East. Had a little sea against us doing 306 miles. The work in ward is now much easier.
Entry.228: Did usual work in the ward. Nothing has happened worth putting down. Still cold. Run for day was 341 miles.
Entry.229:
Not so cold as usual. Sea calm did 330 miles. Same routine in ward. Church

services as usual, but not many there as Chaplains are not liked by the men.
Entry.230: Did usual work in the ward. Two operations to day on Trench feet. Lovely day, but cold at night & early morning. Ship's run for 24 hours was 337 miles. Several of the staff have put in for transfers.
Entry.231: Ship did 330 miles to-day. Concert held at night. Very cold on deck. Put application in for transfer to Infantry.
Entry.232: Did usual work in ward. Ship did 307 miles. Very cold on deck. At night went to see DI patients. One of the Spinal Cases is dying.
Entry.233: Very cold, have not seen the sun for three days. The Spinal case died at 1 am buried at 1 pm. He was also on Peninsula. Kit bags are being searched for any war material. Ship did 317 miles.
Entry.234:
Very rough weather & windy. Did 307 miles

run. Patients received Red Cross issue. Did usual work in ward.
Entry.235: Sea calm. Had concert at night. Run for day was 320 miles.
Entry.236: Church services as usual, very few go to listen to these chaplains as they are not sincere. Had a sun bath in afternoon on deck. Lovely weather. West patients are getting ready to leave.
Entry.237:
Sisters gave patients a very nice farewell supper. They all enjoyed

it immensely. At 7.30 pm a concert was held in the ward, when usual artists assisted in making the evening a success.
Entry.238: Did usual work in ward. Western Australians received their uniforms. Ship did 320 miles run. Sighted Rottnest Island late at night but kept out all night.
Entry.239:
Board of Health Officer came on at 8 am & inspected all on ship. Went into breakwater & made fast to a wharf. Crowd down

to welcome the returning men home. About forty got off. Took on a little coal & water, leaving at 3 pm. Red Cross Ladies brought on fruit for the patients. Madame Bennett-Wilkinson of Perth whome we met last August came down to see us. I had a talk with her for some time. She remembered us all.

Received thirty-nine letters from Australia some aged, some young & up to date. It took all the afternoon to go through them.
Entry.240: Passed Cape Leeuwin about 6.30 am & have kept in sight of land nearly all day. Did usual work in ward. Usual "Wireless" about where the ship is going to - Sea calm. Have not had a rough day since leaving England.
Entry.241: Weather very dull, sea calm. Did usual work in the ward. Patients are looking forward to getting home. Best news of day came out: namely, that the ship is going to Sydney. Run was 320 miles. Church services held, but very few went.
Entry.242: Patients disembarking at Melbourne received their uniforms to day. Weather very cold & dull. Patients had a Red Cross issue.
Entry.243: Usual Divine Services. Very cold on deck so not many went to them. N.S.W. & Qsland patients received their uniforms. They are all getting excited.
Entry.244:
Did usual ward work & put as much gear away as possible, so as to prepare for disembarking tomorrow



A fair swell is on & wind very cold. Did 284 miles, sighted land at 6 pm.
Entry.245:
Arrived at Melbourne at daybreak & waited till about 9 am when after the Board of Health Officer came on we pulled into the Town Pier & disembarked 200 patients. Ship inspected by General Featherstone. Left Melbourne about 1 pm with N.S.W. & s'land patients on board numbering about 150. Patients put in two wards & others

were cleaned up. Passed the "Rip" at 4.30 pm & headed for New South Wales.
Entry.246:
Cleaned up the empty wards all day. Sea rough & weather cloudy with heavy rain.

Packed our curios etc for leaving ship. Excitement as to who is doing guard this time. Patients excited.
Entry.247:
Arrived in sight of "Heads" about 8 am. The pilot came out & we anchored off Watson's Bay, while Board of Health Officer

inspected ship. Pulled into No 1 wharf Woolloomooloo Bay & disembarked patients, who were taken to the Domain & given leave. Cot cases went to No 4 Australian General Hospital. Friends were then allowed on wharf but ship left immediately for Darling Harbour. Had five minutes talk with mother, Bess & Gladys Easterbrook. Given leave from 3 pm till Saturday 14th instant. Went home & very glad to get there. Had visitors at night.
Entry.248:
Stayed home most of day. Went into Water

Board & saw some of the boys. Gave "Cass" negatives. Had visitors for tea & at night went out.
Entry.249:
Up at 8 am. Strange not to hear Reveille yet very pleasant doing without it. Had Breakfast & cleaned up to leave, having to report at ship at noon. All home people look very well. Unfortunately people did not get down to see me off as I thought boat would not go till late whereas it went at 1 pm. Very hard leaving the best spot

on earth, & indeed it is about the prettiest spot we have been to. Passed Kiama at 7 pm. Only about twenty four men on board. All homesick & tired of the "Cruel war".
Entry.250: Very cold on deck, cleaned up a little in the wards. Read most of the time. Passed Gabo Island about 3 pm also S.S. Cooma which left 2 hours before yesterday.
Entry.251: A little swell on. Entered the Heads about 9 am getting to the Town Pier at 1 pm. Leave till 11 am next morning as ship was being fumigated
Entry.252: Wrote a couple of letters in morning, then went on guard. Doing guard duty for 24 hours. A very Keystone one, there being nothing to guard as our armed guard was already posted on gangway. The H.M.A.S. Parramatta came in & fastened near to us, so we have a destroyer of life & one to mend life alongside each other.
Entry.253:
Leave from 11 am till midnight. Had dinner with "Fordy" then went up to get my overcoat at Spencer Street but it did not arrive

Made away to see Mrs Milne & Letty Smith at South Yarra spending evening there. Came back to ship at 11 pm. Very cold out of doors.
Entry.254: Leave from 11 am till midnight. Had dinner the walked around town. Went out to see friends of Katie MacMillan returning to Spencer St to get overcoat. Met several of the boys, when all went out to Zoological Gardens for a couple of hours. Had tea & after to a theatre.
Entry.255:
On guard to day

so wrote several letters. Put rest of day in by reading.
Entry.256: Leave same as usual. Did a little shopping, then having dinner. Maurice Hale & self went out to Mrs Milne's for tea having a little evening at night. I stayed the night. Maurice went back to ship.
Entry.257:
Mr Milne & I went to St Kilda beach for a walk, returning for dinner. In afternoon went out to see an old patient whom I

had looked afteron voyage over, he was at Caulfield Hospital & looks well. It is a fine hospital.
Entry.258: On guard. Public holiday in Melbourne so a great number of people came down to see ship. The procession was not much, & not to be compared with Sydney show.
Entry.259:
Had leave from 3 pm, when remainder of staff returned from their holiday in Sydney.

Hall Fordham & self went for a sail up

the Yarra River, which is very pretty as you leave the city. Went up for about 2 hours when we returned.

Had tea then went to hear Ada Reeves, who by the way is the Karoola favourite, having met her at Bombay in Dec-January when all staff entertained the visitors at Taj-Mahal.
Entry.260:
With seven others of the staff left ship having had our transfers approved. So this ended my stay on the Hospital ship Karoola. Said

Farewell to all my friends on board. She sailed at 11.30 AM. We went to the Victoria Barracks Melbourne, when arrangements were made for our journey over to Sydney. Had lunch then walked around city till it was time to get the train at 4 PM. Had good trip over, there being plenty of room to sleep.
Entry.261: Reported at barracks Sydney, when we were given a pass for two weeks leave. Thus ended my experiences in the Army Medical Corps.
